oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Girls Next Door Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Girls Next Door (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Girls Next Door; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie introduces the Girls Next Door album "How 'Bout Us" and first track "He's Gotta Have Me" -- (00:06) "He's Gotta Have Me" is talked about by Tammy Stephens as an aggressive representation of someone who left and came back -- (00:48) The Girls Next Door joke with Collie and introduce Ricky Van Shelton's "I'll Leave This World Loving You" -- (01:12) "I Called It Love Once" is introduced by Collie and reflected on by Stephens as a representation of changing perspective through education and music -- (02:04) Stephens talks about growing up singing gospel music and being in various different vocal groups through school -- (03:00) An Stephens and Diane Williams talk about performing at the Grand Ole Opry and joining MTM a management company -- (04:21) The album title "How 'Bout Us" is said to be a statement about the various issues the group had beginning their music careers -- (05:02) "One of the Boys" is talked about by Williams as how growing older changed how girls are perceived by their male counter parts -- (05:42) Doris King talks about getting familiar with songs while being on the road -- (06:22) "Maybe You Wouldn't Be Miss'" is talked about by Cindy Nixon and King about how they perceived it to be a single soon and the upcoming video -- (08:14) Williams introduces K.T. Oslin's "I'll Always Come Back" -- (08:23) Collie introduces the group and Williams talks about being a part of an air force family and moving around from Belgium, Germany to Denver, Colorado and eventually moving to Nashville, Tennessee -- (09:00) Nixon talks about how she's one of the few artists born in Nashville and having a great deal of country music influencing her youth -- (09:48) King talks about growing up in Nashville and her exposure to music and love of horses -- (10:35) "Few Good Men" is described by King as a song for a women that needs multiple good men to heal her -- (11:01) "How Can They Call This Cheating" is told by Williams as a song by a female artist in a male dominated field -- (12:14) Williams says "Here's my favorite Steve Wariner song" -- (12:18) "It's Too Late" is told as by King that their engineer (Nelson Larken) does not tell them who writes the song to avoid bias -- (13:21) "Last Goodbye" and the Girls Next Door are introduced by Collie -- (13:33) Williams explains "Last Goodbye" as a 'honky tonk' type song -- (14:02) Stephens talks about a time where they traveled in a van and being confronted by a man about not having a fiddle -- (14:52) Nixon talks about a fan who bought five copies of their album -- (15:29) Nixon thinks about a song to play and "Restless Heart" by Wheels is introduced -- (15:50) Collie and Girls Next Door talk about the ease of having a three word named band -- (16:25) "Wasn't It You" is discussed by King as the most traditional song about mistreatment -- (16:55) Nixon describes "Wasn't It You" as a song about someone who left that comes back -- (17:22) Collie and Girls Next Door discuss that this is the first show they have ever done their entire album and been a performing disc jockey -- (18:10) Girls Next Door thank Collie for being there and talk about purchasing their album -- (19:13) Girls Next Door Say Goodbye
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Girls Next Door (Musical group); Collie, Biff;
